deliberation: Narrative description of Pashhur's identity and his hearing Jeremiah prophesy. No metaphorical or idiomatic uses; temple terminology and titles appear to be straightforward and literal.

Describes Pashhur striking Jeremiah and putting him in the מַהְפֶּכֶת (stocks/cell) at a specific gate. The language is descriptive and concrete; even if the precise nature of המהפכת is debated, it denotes a physical restraining device, not an image for something else.

Jeremiah renames Pashhur with the symbolic name מָגוֹר מִסָּבִיב (terror on every side). This is a prophetic name-metaphor: the phrase of pervasive terror is transferred to Pashhur as his identity and destiny. The rest of the verse is literal.

instances.hebrew_text: לֹ֤א פַשְׁחוּר֙ קָרָ֤א יְהוָה֙ שְׁמֶ֔ךָ כִּ֖י אִם־מָג֥וֹר מִסָּבִֽיב
instances.english_text: GOD has named you not Pashhur, but Magor-missabib (Terror-all-around).
vehicle: מָגוֹר מִסָּבִיב, a formula for pervasive terror used as a name
a condition of being surrounded by fear and disaster
emotional and experiential domain of panic and siege
ground: Pashhur will be encompassed and defined by terror and calamity
inescapable, all‑around danger and fear
divine judgment imagery
posture: Jeremiah’s ironic re‑naming of an official associated with security as Terror‑on‑every‑side
instances.explanation: The stereotyped expression 'terror all around' is turned into Pashhur’s new name, metaphorically defining his identity by the terror and disaster that will surround him. It also carries ironic force, replacing his given name with a name of doom.

deliberation: Judgment oracle. Notable figurative elements: (1) 'I am giving you to terror' treats terror as a master/realm to which someone can be handed over; (2) 'into the hand of the king of Babylon' uses 'hand' as a metonym for power/control; (3) 'fall by the sword' uses 'sword' as a metonym for violent death/warfare. These are distinct conventional figures.

instances.english_text: I am going to deliver you and all your friends over to terror.

historical experience of conquest and exile
vehicle: being handed over to 'terror' as if to a captor or domain
a hostile power or realm exercising control
domain of psychological and military oppression
ground: terror will dominate and control them as a master controls captives
total subjection to frightening, destructive forces
imagery of conquest and captivity re-applied to emotional/spiritual dread
instances.explanation: Terror is treated like a power to whom people can be 'given,' personifying fear as a captor and metaphorically describing the total domination Pashhur and his allies will experience.

instances.english_text: I will deliver [them] into the hand of the king of Babylon.

physical hand as a symbol of power and control

transfer of control from one power to another
concept of sovereignty and mastery
posture: prophetic description of conquest in covenantal terms
legal-transfer imagery applied to political domination
instances.explanation: The 'hand' of the king stands metonymically for his power and control. To be given into his 'hand' is an idiomatic way to say that Judah will come under his dominion.

instances.english_text: They will fall by the sword of their enemies ... and he will strike them with the sword.
vehicle: the 'sword' as the agent
weapon representing warfare and killing
instrumental metonymy for military violence

the weapon stands for the act and event of slaughter
shared association of sword with war and death
posture: announcement of concrete but also theologically charged violence
instances.explanation: The 'sword' functions as a metonym for warfare and violent death. Saying they will 'fall by the sword' is a conventional idiom for being killed in battle.

deliberation: Continues judgment: wealth and treasures are given 'into the hand of their enemies,' using the same idiom as v.4. That is a metonymy/idiom for coming under someone’s power. The rest is literal description of plunder.

instances.english_text: I will deliver [them] into the hand of their enemies.

vehicle: the 'hand' of the enemies

posture: prophetic portrayal of looting as divinely decreed transfer
instances.explanation: Again 'hand' is metonymy for the enemies’ power. To give the city’s wealth 'into the hand' of enemies is an idiomatic way of saying they will fully control and plunder it.

deliberation: Predicts literal exile, death, and burial in Babylon for Pashhur and his household. 'House' for family is a normal social term here, not an image. No clear metaphors or special idioms beyond standard prose.

Jeremiah speaks of God 'enticing' and 'overpowering' him, using seduction and combat imagery for his prophetic call—these are metaphors applied to God. Then he says he has become 'a laughingstock all day; everyone mocks me,' an exaggerated, idiomatic way of describing constant public ridicule.

instances.english_text: You enticed me, O LORD, and I was enticed; You overpowered me and You prevailed.
target: Jeremiah’s experience of being compelled into prophetic service
the inner process of prophetic vocation
vehicle: being seduced and overpowered in struggle
romantic/sexual persuasion and military defeat
domains of interpersonal attraction and physical combat
ground: Jeremiah’s will was overcome despite resistance
loss of control and yielding under a stronger influence
asymmetry of power between God and prophet
posture: complaint accusing God of coercive treatment
lamenting tone bordering on ironic accusation
instances.explanation: Jeremiah uses the language of seduction and overpowering to describe how God’s call overcame his resistance. This is metaphorical and deliberately provocative, casting God as a powerful suitor or conqueror.

instances.hebrew_text: הָיִ֤יתִי לִשְׂחוֹק֙ כׇּל־הַיּ֔וֹם כֻּלֹּ֖ה לֹעֵ֥ג לִֽי

ongoing, pervasive mockery that defines his public identity
association of laughter with humiliation
instances.explanation: By saying he has 'become a laughingstock all day' and 'everyone' mocks him, Jeremiah uses hyperbolic, idiomatic language to portray himself as nothing but an object of ridicule.

deliberation: Jeremiah summarizes his message ('violence and destruction') and its result: 'the word of YHWH has become for me a reproach and derision all day.' The 'word of YHWH' here stands metonymically for the prophetic commission/message and its social consequences, which become shame for him.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּֽי־הָיָ֨ה דְבַר־יְהוָ֥ה לִ֛י לְחֶרְפָּ֥ה וּלְקֶ֖לֶס כׇּל־הַיּֽוֹם
instances.english_text: For the word of the LORD has become for me a reproach and derision all day.

the burden and consequences of his vocation
intersection of revelation and social response

a message perceived as shameful abuse
domain of social stigma
ground: carrying and speaking the divine word results in continual shame
what should be honorable instead brings disgrace
paradox of divine message producing scorn
posture: complaint about the cost of ministry
instances.explanation: The 'word of the LORD' functions both metonymically for Jeremiah’s prophetic commission and metaphorically as if it were itself 'reproach and derision.' The phrase 'all day' heightens the sense of unrelenting disgrace.

deliberation: Jeremiah resolves not to speak in God’s name, but then describes the inner compulsion: the word is 'like a burning fire in my heart, shut up in my bones.' This is a vivid simile extended into bodily metaphor; it pictures the message as fire imprisoned within him, making silence impossible.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיָ֤ה בְלִבִּי֙ כְּאֵ֣שׁ בֹּעֶ֔רֶת עָצֻ֖ר בְּעַצְמֹתָ֑י
instances.english_text: But [his word] was in my heart like a burning fire, shut up in my bones.
target: Jeremiah’s inner experience of prophetic compulsion
emotional and spiritual state of the prophet

uncontrollable, destructive heat seeking release
domain of physical sensation and natural force
ground: intense, painful pressure that demands expression
impossibility of suppressing something so powerful
shared features of fire’s energy and the urge to speak
posture: lament mixed with acknowledgment of divine power
instances.explanation: Jeremiah likens the divine word inside him to a blazing fire trapped within his very bones, an image that captures both the pain of restraint and the inevitability of his speaking.

deliberation: Jeremiah reports hearing 'terror on every side' and describes his supposed friends 'watching for my stumbling.' 'Terror on every side' reprises the set phrase מגור מסביב for pervasive fear, and 'stumbling' is metaphorical for failing or falling into misfortune.

instances.english_text: The whisperings of many: Terror all around!
vehicle: מָגוֹר מִסָּבִיב, 'terror all around'
a state of being surrounded by dread and danger
emotional and military-siege imagery
ground: Jeremiah is encircled by hostility and threat
sense that danger presses in from every side
blend of fear and actual plotting
posture: report of hostile gossip and atmosphere
instances.explanation: The slogan-like phrase 'terror all around' is a conventional image for pervasive, inescapable fear and danger, characterizing the environment that surrounds Jeremiah.

instances.english_text: All the men of my peace are watching for my stumbling.

vehicle: stumbling (צלע) while people watch
a person tripping or falling under observation
physical movement and misstep

his 'friends' eagerly await a misstep that will ruin him
connection between physical and moral/ vocational collapse
posture: use of idiomatic fall-language for ruin
lament about malicious intent among intimates
instances.explanation: Jeremiah’s 'men of peace' are said to watch for his 'stumbling,' a common metaphor in Hebrew where physical stumbling represents failure or calamity.

deliberation: Jeremiah contrasts God’s support with his enemies’ fate. 'The LORD is with me like a mighty warrior' is an explicit simile; 'my pursuers will stumble' again uses the metaphor of stumbling for failure or ruin.

instances.english_text: But the LORD is with me like a mighty warrior.

reframing of circumstances through martial metaphor
instances.explanation: Jeremiah compares God’s presence to that of a formidable warrior standing by his side, emphasizing divine strength and protection in the face of persecution.

instances.english_text: Therefore my persecutors shall stumble and not prevail.

losing footing and falling in a pursuit

ground: their attempts will be thwarted and collapse
stumbling symbolizes defeat and frustration of plans
connection between loss of balance and loss of success
instances.explanation: As in v.10, physical 'stumbling' is a metaphor for failing in one’s efforts. Jeremiah asserts that his persecutors will trip up and be unable to prevail.

deliberation: God is described as one who 'sees kidneys and heart.' In Hebrew anthropology 'kidneys and heart' metonymically/synecdochically represent the inner thoughts, motives, and emotions. This is a standard but still figurative way of speaking of the inmost self.

instances.english_text: Who examines the kidneys and the heart.

body-part terminology

to see them is to know a person’s true inner state
metonymic link between organs and inward character
posture: appeal to God’s perfect knowledge and justice
prayer for vindication based on divine omniscience
instances.explanation: ‘Kidneys and heart’ stand metonymically for the inner being. Saying that God sees them means he knows the deepest thoughts and motives of people.

deliberation: Praise verse. Two small figures: 'soul of the needy' uses 'soul' as synecdoche for the whole person, and 'hand of evildoers' uses 'hand' as metonym for their power or grasp.

instances.english_text: the soul of the needy one
target: the whole needy person whom God rescues
vehicle: נֶפֶשׁ (soul/life) as the referent
life or self as a part/aspect of the person
inner-life terminology
ground: soul stands for the living person in their vulnerability
focus on the life at stake rather than possessions
association of נֶפֶשׁ with the living self
posture: celebration of God’s care for the weak
instances.explanation: Here 'soul' is a common synecdoche for the whole person, emphasizing the life that God has preserved.

instances.english_text: from the hand of evildoers
target: the power and control of wicked people over the needy
vehicle: the 'hand' of evildoers
hand as symbol of power, grasp, and control

deliverance from the 'hand' means liberation from control
association of hands with exertion of power
instances.explanation: The 'hand' of evildoers stands metonymically for their power over victims; God rescues the needy from their grasp.

deliberation: Jeremiah curses the day of his birth and says, 'Let not the day be blessed.' A 'day' cannot literally be cursed or blessed; this is hyperbolic, personifying the day as if it could receive blessing or cursing to express extreme self‑loathing and regret.

instances.hebrew_text: אָר֣וּר הַיּ֔וֹם אֲשֶׁ֥ר יֻלַּ֖דְתִּי בּ֑וֹ ... אַל־יְהִ֥י בָרֽוּךְ
instances.english_text: Accursed be the day that I was born! Let not the day be blessed when my mother bore me!
target: Jeremiah’s own existence and life history
vehicle: cursing or blessing a 'day' as if it were a subject
treating a calendar day as an accursed entity
ritual-language applied to time
ground: the birthday symbolizes his entire troubled life
to curse the day is to reject the whole fact of his existence
link between beginnings and subsequent suffering
posture: hyperbolic rejection of one’s own life
instances.explanation: Jeremiah personifies and curses the very day of his birth as a way of rejecting his existence; this is hyperbolic lament language, not a literal curse on a date.

deliberation: Jeremiah extends his curse to the man who brought his father the birth news. Wishing a curse on the messenger is rhetorical hyperbole: he does not know or literally target that herald, but uses him as a figure for the whole event of his birth.

instances.hebrew_text: אָר֣וּר הָאִ֗ישׁ אֲשֶׁ֨ר בִּשַּׂ֤ר אֶת־אָבִי֙ לֵאמֹ֔ר יֻֽלַּד־לְךָ֖ בֵּ֣ן זָכָ֑ר
instances.english_text: Accursed be the man who brought my father the news and said, 'A boy is born to you.'
target: Jeremiah’s birth event and the joy surrounding it
the origin of his troubled life
vehicle: cursing the joyful messenger of good news
treating the herald as deserving doom
social role of messenger as focus of blame
ground: the messenger represents the event he announced
by cursing the messenger he symbolically curses the birth itself
intense wish that the joyful announcement had never occurred
posture: hyperbolic lament intensifying the curse of v.14
use of metonymic target to dramatize self-rejection
instances.explanation: The man who brought the birth news stands metonymically for the whole event of Jeremiah’s birth. Cursing him is a hyperbolic way of rejecting the fact of his existence and the joy it caused.

deliberation: Jeremiah wishes that that man become 'like the cities that the LORD overthrew,' an explicit simile evoking Sodom-type destruction. The battle cries morning and noon may be literal wishes for constant terror, but the key figurative element is the comparison to overthrown cities.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיָה֙ הָאִ֣ישׁ הַה֔וּא כֶּעָרִ֛ים אֲשֶׁר־הָפַ֥ךְ יְהוָ֖ה וְלֹ֣א נִחָ֑ם
instances.english_text: Let that man become like the cities that the LORD overthrew and did not relent.
target: the imagined fate of the birth messenger
vehicle: cities overthrown by God without relenting (e.g., Sodom-like)
total, irrevocable destruction of urban centers
domain of catastrophic judgment narratives
ground: desire for complete, pitiless ruin
link between the cities’ exemplary destruction and the wished fate of the man
symbolic use of well-known judgment precedent
posture: invocation of traditional judgment imagery as curse
instances.explanation: The man is compared to cities that God destroyed without pity, a hyperbolic simile that uses the stock image of Sodom-like devastation to express Jeremiah’s intense anguish.

deliberation: Jeremiah imagines God killing him 'from the womb' so that 'my mother would be my grave, and her womb pregnant forever.' The mother’s womb is metaphorically cast as his grave, with the phrase 'pregnant forever' hyperbolically extending the image.

instances.hebrew_text: וַתְּהִי־לִ֤י אִמִּי֙ קִבְרִ֔י וְרַחְמָ֖הּ הֲרַ֥ת עוֹלָֽם
instances.english_text: So that my mother might be my grave, and her womb pregnant forever.
target: his desire that his life had ended before birth
vehicle: the mother as a grave; her womb as eternally pregnant
burial place and unending gestation
domains of death and pregnancy merged
ground: remaining in the womb would be equivalent to being buried
he longs for a state where he never emerges into life’s sorrow
use of paradox (eternal pregnancy) to stress impossibility and wish
posture: shocking imagery to express desire never to have lived
poetic fusion of birth and death motifs
instances.explanation: Jeremiah pictures his mother as his 'grave' and her womb as perpetually pregnant, a metaphoric and hyperbolic way to wish that he had died in utero and never been born.

deliberation: Jeremiah asks why he came forth from the womb 'to see' misery and sorrow and have his days 'end in shame.' 'See' in Hebrew regularly means 'experience,' and the phrasing about his days ending in shame can be taken straightforwardly as life ending in disgrace. The verse is intensely emotional but does not introduce a distinct, non-conventional image beyond standard lament diction.
